metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: HTML Forms
An HTML form is used to collect user input. The user input is most often sent to a server for processing.
content.html: An HTML form is used to collect user input. The user input is most often sent to a server for processing.

content.text: The <form> Element
The HTML <form> element is used to create an HTML form for user input:
content.html: The HTML <form> element is used to create an HTML form for user input:

content.code_html:
<form>
.
form elements
.
</form>

content.text: The <form> element is a container for different types of input elements, such as: text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, etc.
content.html: The <form> element is a container for different types of input elements, such as: text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, etc.

content.text: All the different form elements are covered in this chapter: HTML Form Elements .
content.html: All the different form elements are covered in this chapter: HTML Form Elements.

content.text: The <input> Element
The HTML <input> element is the most used form element.
content.html: The HTML <input> element is the most used form element.

content.text: An <input> element can be displayed in many ways, depending on the type attribute.
content.html: An <input> element can be displayed in many ways, depending on the type attribute.

content.text: Here are some examples:
content.html: Here are some examples:

content.text: All the different input types are covered in this chapter: HTML Input Types .
content.html: All the different input types are covered in this chapter: HTML Input Types.

content.text: Text Fields
The <input type="text"> defines a single-line input field for text input.
content.html: The <input type="text"> defines a single-line input field for text input.

content.code_html:
<form>
  <label for="fname">First name:</label><br>
  <input type="text" id="fname" name="fname"><br>
  <label for="lname">Last name:</label><br>
  <input type="text" id="lname" name="lname">
</form>

content.text: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:
content.html: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:

content.text: Note: The form itself is not visible. Also note that the default width of an input field is 20 characters.
content.html: Note: The form itself is not visible. Also note that the default width of an input field is 20 characters.

content.text: The <label> Element
Notice the use of the <label> element in the example above.
content.html: Notice the use of the <label> element in the example above.

content.text: The <label> tag defines a label for many form elements.
content.html: The <label> tag defines a label for many form elements.

content.text: The <label> element is useful for screen-reader users, because the screen-reader will read out loud the label when the user focuses on the input element.
content.html: The <label> element is useful for screen-reader users, because the screen-reader will read out loud the label when the user focuses on the input element.

content.text: The <label> element also helps users who have difficulty clicking on very small regions (such as radio buttons or checkboxes) - because when the user clicks the text within the <label> element, it toggles the radio button/checkbox.
content.html: The <label> element also helps users who have difficulty clicking on very small regions (such as radio buttons or checkboxes) - because when the user clicks the text within the <label> element, it toggles the radio button/checkbox.

content.text: The for attribute of the <label> tag should be equal to the id attribute of the <input> element to bind them together.
content.html: The for attribute of the <label> tag should be equal to the id attribute of the <input> element to bind them together.

content.text: Radio Buttons
The <input type="radio"> defines a radio button.
content.html: The <input type="radio"> defines a radio button.

content.text: Radio buttons let a user select ONE of a limited number of choices.
content.html: Radio buttons let a user select ONE of a limited number of choices.

content.code: Choose your favorite Web language:
content.code_html:
<p>Choose your favorite Web language:</p>

<form>
  <input type="radio" id="html" name="fav_language" value="HTML">
  <label for="html">HTML</label><br>
  <input type="radio" id="css" name="fav_language" value="CSS">
  <label for="css">CSS</label><br>
  <input type="radio" id="javascript" name="fav_language" value="JavaScript">
  <label for="javascript">JavaScript</label>
</form>

content.text: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:
content.html: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:

content.text: Choose your favorite Web language:
content.html: Choose your favorite Web language:

content.text: Checkboxes
The <input type="checkbox"> defines a checkbox .
content.html: The <input type="checkbox"> defines a checkbox.

content.text: Checkboxes let a user select ZERO or MORE options of a limited number of choices.
content.html: Checkboxes let a user select ZERO or MORE options of a limited number of choices.

content.code_html:
<form>
  <input type="checkbox" id="vehicle1" name="vehicle1" value="Bike">
  <label for="vehicle1"> I have a bike</label><br>
  <input type="checkbox" id="vehicle2" name="vehicle2" value="Car">
  <label for="vehicle2"> I have a car</label><br>
  <input type="checkbox" id="vehicle3" name="vehicle3" value="Boat">
  <label for="vehicle3"> I have a boat</label>
</form>

content.text: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:
content.html: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:

content.text: The Submit Button
The <input type="submit"> defines a button for submitting the form data to a form-handler.
content.html: The <input type="submit"> defines a button for submitting the form data to a form-handler.

content.text: The form-handler is typically a file on the server with a script for processing input data.
content.html: The form-handler is typically a file on the server with a script for processing input data.

content.text: The form-handler is specified in the form's action attribute.
content.html: The form-handler is specified in the form's action attribute.

content.code_html:
<form action="/action_page.php">
  <label for="fname">First name:</label><br>
  <input type="text" id="fname" name="fname" value="John"><br>
  <label for="lname">Last name:</label><br>
  <input type="text" id="lname" name="lname" value="Doe"><br><br>
  <input type="submit" value="Submit">
</form>

content.text: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:
content.html: This is how the HTML code above will be displayed in a browser:

content.text: The Name Attribute for <input>
Notice that each input field must have a name attribute to be submitted.
content.html: Notice that each input field must have a name attribute to be submitted.

content.text: If the name attribute is omitted, the value of the input field will not be sent at all.
content.html: If the name attribute is omitted, the value of the input field will not be sent at all.

content.code_html:
<form action="/action_page.php">
  <label for="fname">First name:</label><br>
  <input type="text" id="fname" value="John"><br><br>
  <input type="submit" value="Submit">
</form>

What is the correct HTML element for defining a form?
content.html: What is the correct HTML element for defining a form?
